messageBody:
Steve Freeman wrote:

> From: "Matt Caswell" <m.caswell@...>
>
>> circumstances. However I think I would be reluctant to change the way my
>
>
>> code was implemented just so that I could test it, as some of the other
>
>
>
>
> My experience is different. I've found that changing my coding style to make it testable (which doesn't mean just putting in lots of unnecessary accessors) also makes it better. The more I apply this to different targets, such as shell scripts, the more I'm convinced.
>
>
>
> Steve
>

I concur. I've found that testable code exhibits certain composable
properties that foster interface-based design. For example, the
assembly of a few simple objects to perform a more complex task allows
any of the objects to be mocked. In turn, by refactoring designs to
extract complex static relationships into interface-based compositions,
the design becomes more open to extension, but closed to modification.
So, I'll up the ante and claim that designs may change as a side effect
of writing tests. This is the essence of test-first design.

Mike
